newsitem.title: CHILE: Chilean minister opens Andacollo copper mine.
newsitem.headline: Chilean minister opens Andacollo copper mine.

text.p: Chilean Mining Minister Bejamin Teplizky on Thursday opened officially the Canadian-owned Carmen de Andacollo copper mine in north Chile.
The mine, owned by Canada Tungsten Inc, is small by Chilean standards with a design capacity of 20,000 tonnes of copper cathodes a year.
But exploration has shown that the pit has additional mineral reserves which which could extend its active life, currently 11 years.

"Operators and technicians have told us that the Andacollo copper mine has at its limits a second mineralized body which is much larger than reserves currently being exploited," said Teplizky in a speech at the openeing ceremony.
This ore body may have reserves of around 600 million tonnes of mineral with a copper grade of 0.4 percent, he said.
The mine, which cost $84 million to build, produces fine copper using low-cost heap-leaching technology.
Canada Tungsten owns 63 percent of the pit, with Chile's Compania Minera del Pacifico holding 27 percent and 10 percent held by state mining company Enami.
